title.$t: Imagine Domestic Violence at a Restaurant

media$title.$t: Imagine Domestic Violence at a Restaurant

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/BnZ6/

Directed & Edited by
Jules Dameron

Produced by
Trina Licht
Julie Rems Smario

Cinematographers
Jules Dameron
Gungaa Tuvshinbat

Sound Designer
Jackie Wellons

Cast
JAC Cook
Daniel J. Girard
Jennie Batchelder
Azora Telford

Rory Osbrink - ASL Narrator

Photographer 
Ken Arcia 

Concept Created by the DeafHope Team

Special thanks to Mozzeria 

http://www.deaf-hope.org
http://www.julesdameron.com
________________________
TRANSCRIPT

Scene appears to be a restaurant.

A cheerful woman (JAC) is sitting at a table. She says "So, how have you been? How's your wife?"

A man (Dan) is sitting across him. He replies, "Oh, she's doing great. Been enjoying staying at home."

Close up of a woman (Jennie) next to the man. She looks uncomfortable and sad. Her eyes are down. 

JAC smiles and says "That's good."

Another woman (Azora), next to JAC, nods with her eyes down. 

Jennie looks uncomfortable and looks to Azora.  

Azora gives a small smile and appears to be about to say something. JAC holds her hand down and says "shut up." 

Jennie looks on as JAC says "you interrupted the conversation." 

Azora looks down and nods again. Jennie gives her a sympathetic look. 

Dan sees Jennie giving Azora the look. He stands up and moves close to Jennie, almost pushing her over.  He holds her chin and pushes her face towards him. He moves her shoulder so she's sitting up straight. Jennie looks extremely uncomfortable. Dan returns to his seat and looks like he's in charge.

JAC says "We just love to be together. We hang out all the time." 

Dan says "I get you. We've been so dedicated to each other."

Jennie looks down and fidgets in her seat.

Dan reaches over and touches Jennie's face and says "I love you." Jennie gives a small smile. Dan stares at her and holds her face again. He pulls her roughly towards him and kisses her cheek. Jennie grimaces and pulls away. 

In the background, JAC says "That's so adorable."

JAC says "We bought a house.  I did all the decorations myself." She looks over at Azora and sees that she's texting on her phone. JAC slams the table and signs angrily, "Not again!" Azora tries to explain herself and says "Wait. I'm sorry. I'm sorry." 

JAC puts her hands on Azora's throat. Azora says again "I'm sorry." JAC lets her go as Azora turns away while coughing. 

Close up shot of Azora coughing and saying "I'm sorry."

Jennie looks on looking fearful. She looks away.  A woman at another table is looking at her.

Dan checks out what Jennie is looking at. He notices the other woman and grabs Jennie's head and slams it onto the table. 

Jennie holds her head in pain. 

JAC and Dan raise their wine glasses and toasts. Jennie holds her head and Azora is breathing hard. 

Black background with white text: 90% of domestic violence happens at home.

Domestic violence is not a private matter. 

Take a stand against domestic violence. 

A black and white shot of a man appears. He says, "Domestic violence cannot be ignored. Get involved."

DeafHope's logo appears. It is a drawing of a woman holding an infant with one hand and signing ILY with another. Text appears: "Our mission at DeafHope is to end domestic and sexual violence against Deaf women and children through empowerment, education, and services." 

"Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women." 

"www.deaf-hope.org"

Logos for Blue Shield of California and Verizon Foundation appear.

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/BnZ6/

Scene appears to be a restaurant.

A cheerful woman (JAC) is sitting at a table. She says "So, how have you been? How's your wife?"

Close up of a woman (Jennie) next to the man. She looks uncomfortable and sad. Her eyes are down. 

JAC smiles and says "That's good."

Azora gives a small smile and appears to be about to say something. JAC holds her hand down and says "shut up." 

Jennie looks on as JAC says "you interrupted the conversation." 

Azora looks down and nods again. Jennie gives her a sympathetic look. 

Dan sees Jennie giving Azora the look. He stands up and moves close to Jennie, almost pushing her over.  He holds her chin and pushes her face towards him. He moves her shoulder so she's sitting up straight. Jennie looks extremely uncomfortable. Dan returns to his seat and looks like he's in charge.

JAC says "We just love to be together. We hang out all the time." 

Dan says "I get you. We've been so dedicated to each other."

Jennie looks down and fidgets in her seat.

Dan reaches over and touches Jennie's face and says "I love you." Jennie gives a small smile. Dan stares at her and holds her face again. He pulls her roughly towards him and kisses her cheek. Jennie grimaces and pulls away. 

In the background, JAC says "That's so adorable."

JAC says "We bought a house.  I did all the decorations myself." She looks over at Azora and sees that she's texting on her phone. JAC slams the table and signs angrily, "Not again!" Azora tries to explain herself and says "Wait. I'm sorry. I'm sorry." 

JAC puts her hands on Azora's throat. Azora says again "I'm sorry." JAC lets her go as Azora turns away while coughing. 

Close up shot of Azora coughing and saying "I'm sorry."

Jennie looks on looking fearful. She looks away.  A woman at another table is looking at her.

Dan checks out what Jennie is looking at. He notices the other woman and grabs Jennie's head and slams it onto the table. 

Jennie holds her head in pain. 

JAC and Dan raise their wine glasses and toasts. Jennie holds her head and Azora is breathing hard. 

Black background with white text: 90% of domestic violence happens at home.

Domestic violence is not a private matter.

A black and white shot of a man appears. He says, "Domestic violence cannot be ignored. Get involved."

DeafHope's logo appears. It is a drawing of a woman holding an infant with one hand and signing ILY with another. Text appears: "Our mission at DeafHope is to end domestic and sexual violence against Deaf women and children through empowerment, education, and services."

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/BsKD/

TRANSCRIPT

Image of the original Dare to Utter Cast Announcement Flyer

White background with black text: Some of the cast took a training on domestic and sexual violence provided by DeafHope.

White background with black text: How did you feel after taking the domestic and sexual violence training?

Sandra Thrapp: "I'm overwhelmed. Very empowering. I really cherish this."

Tanja Bierschneider: "This feels very supportive. You know, it's like there are many layers. I think I know all of them, but there are actually deeper layers to this issue. It's like there's a checklist, and I just realized there are more things to check off. I really enjoyed this- very supportive. It's awesome."

Christina McMurry: "Before I came here, I felt my experience was silenced. When I came here, I realize many of us have the same experience. I feel we didn't have that chance or the opportunity to be able to discuss our experiences. And now I see everybody here, I know I''m not the only one. Why couldn't this have happened a long time ago? Why now?" 

Leila Hanaumi: "Rape culture is a very real thing. All of us have experienced or know someone who has experienced sexual violence or domestic violence. All of us. So, we really have to change our thinking, change our teachings. Don't teach our girls not to get raped, teach our boys not to rape." 

Cara Barnett: "The idea of rape culture has been very vague. I think it's time to make it clear. Show what rape culture means."

Sel Staley: "Rape can happen to anyone."

Roz Ramos: "I've learned so much from this workshop. I realize it's about community accountability. I used to not want to be involved. I thought it wasn't my business. No, community accountability means we need to help each other. We need allies to support us."

Pictures of the cast appear one by one.

Sandra Thrapp

Roz Ramos

Antonine Hunter

Cara Barnett

Tanja Bierschneider

Christina McMurry

Leila Hanaumi

Shira Grabelsky

Sel Staley

Leala Holcomb

Chris Joseph

Rima Cornish

www.deaf-hope.org

Picture of the original flyer appears: DARE TO UTTER Friday April 19, 2013 7-9pm at Deaf Community Center

Tickets at: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/358988

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/BsKD/

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/BsKK/

TRANSCRIPT:

Text: DeafHope Announcement April 2013

Three women appear with a mosaic with "DeafHope" in the background. 

The woman on the right says: "Hi, I'm Jane Whitney." 

The woman in the middle says: "Hi, I'm Amber Hodson."

The woman on the left says: "Hi, I'm Tara Holcomb." 

The screen fades to Amber standing alone. "DeafHope Board and Staff are taking another step towards social justice. A way of doing that is to create a flat organization to represent our community goal of equal and shared power."

Fades to Tara. "That means we will not have one Executive Director. Instead, we all will become Empowerment Directors. We will contribute what we can with our various strengths and skills."

Fades to Jane. "As a team, we will use those talents to make sure all service needs are met. We welcome you to contribute your talents to DeafHope as well."

Fades to Amber. "Our focus will be on building the community capacity to support survivors by training agencies."

Fades to Tara. "Encouraging individual and community accountability."

Fades to Jane. "Providing information and education through social media."

Fades to Amber. "We will continue to support survivors in emergency situations."

Fades to Tara. "We will connect you to agencies that provide empowering services." 

Fades to Jane. "The best way to contact our team is to e-mail deafhope@deaf-hope.org. One of our fabulous EDs will respond."

Back to all three women standing together. "Together we can end violence."

Screen fades to black with white text: www.deaf-hope.org

media$description.$t:
Directed & Edited by 
Jules Dameron  

Produced by 
Trina Licht
 Julie Rems Smario

  Cinematographers 
Jules Dameron 
Gungaa Tuvshinbat

  Sound Designer
 Jackie Wellons

  Cast in Order of Appearance  
Leala Holcomb 
Martin Dale-Hench
 Alejandra Cisneros
 Ken Arcia 
Alyce Slater Reynolds 
Antoine Hunter 
Orkid Sassouni
 Zane Pedersen
 David Prince 

Bemnet Tesfasilasie - ASL Narrator

  Photographer  Ken Arcia

Concept Created by the DeafHope Team

  http://www.deaf-hope.org 
http://www.julesdameron.com

_________________________

TRANSCRIPT:

Black background with white text: Domestic Violence: Victim Blaming.

A upset woman appears in bed. She says "I'm not in the mood for sex. I want to sleep." 

An angry looking man looks down at the woman, saying "Shut up! You asked for it." 

He puts his hands around the woman's neck as she looks away and tries to struggle against him. 

The screen turns black.

A young woman walks down a hall saying "The fact they're even together is her fault."

A man sits at his office saying, "She can be difficult."

A woman stands at a kitchen, mixing something in a bowl saying, "He has a history. She knows better."

A man sits on a couch saying, "Ya know what? She's trying to put him on a leash. You know? It's like he's pussy-whipped."

A woman drives a car saying, "I know he's abusive but she's strong and can handle it." 

A teenage boy is playing basketball saying "She can be a bitch."

Three men are sitting next to each other playing poker. The man in the middle says, "That's impossible. He's a good guy." He looks at his right. 

A young man appears in black and white. He says, "Are you sure you're blaming the right person?"

Text: Victim blaming allows violence to continue. It's never the survivor's fault. 

DeafHope's logo appears with the words: Our mission at DeafHope is to end domestic and sexual violence against Deaf women and children through empowerment, education, and services. 

Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women. 

www.deaf-hope.org

The logos of Blue Shield of California foundation and Verizon appear.

Directed & Edited by
 Jules Dameron

  Produced by 
Trina Licht
 Julie Rems Smario

Jules Dameron

Jackie Wellons  

Cast
 Tracy Seto - Wife
 David Seto - Husband  

Photographer 
 Ken Arcia

Concept Created by the DeafHope Team

  http://www.deaf-hope.org 
http://www.julesdameron.com
________________________

TRANSCRIPT:

Black background with white text: Sexual Consent 

A topless man is sitting in bed. A woman wearing a black nightie climbs into bed with him. She looks at him, turns away, and lies down. The man puts away his phone, leans in, and kisses the woman on the shoulder. He reaches over with his hand and kisses her shoulder again. The woman looks up at him and asks him "what are you doing?" He pulls away and says "I'm sorry. I just wanted to kiss you." The woman smiles, turns over, and says "okay." The man reaches over with his arm and pulls her closer. They kiss. The man puts his hand on her shoulder and gently pulls down the strap of her nightie. He rubs her shoulder. The woman stops him by holding his hand. She pulls back and says "I want to take it easy." The man says "okay" and puts the strap back on her shoulder. He smiles and says "it's fine." He asks again "you okay?" while kissing her. He says "I love you." The woman says "I love you too." The scene fades to black. 

Words appear: Sex with consent is SEXY. Sex without consent is RAPE. 

The bedroom scene appears again. The couple is blurred and they are under the covers. Words appear: Consent is sexy.

Fades to black background.

DeafHope's logo appears with the words: Our mission at DeafHope is to end domestic and sexual violence against Deaf women and children through empowerment, education, and services. 

Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women. 

www.deaf-hope.org

The logos of Blue Shield of California foundation and Verizon appear.

title.$t: What does COMMUNITY ACCOUNTABILITY look like?

media$title.$t: What does COMMUNITY ACCOUNTABILITY look like?

media$description.$t:
Directed & Edited by
Jules Dameron

Produced by
Trina Licht
Julie Rems Smario

Cinematographers
Jules Dameron
Gungaa Tuvshinbat

Sound Designer
Jackie Wellons

Cast in Order of Appearance

Melinda Harrison Jones - Survivor
Rose Crisman - Survivor's Daughter
Ian Jones - Abuser
Alexandria Brinkley-Green - Runner
Christina McMurry - Driver
Lilly Crisman - Friend
David Smario - EMT
Trina Licht - Second Survivor
Bobby Cox - Partygoer #1
Leala Holcomb - Partygoer #2
Orkid Sassouni - Partygoer #3
Martin Dale-Hench - Partygoer #4
Antoine Hunter - Partygoer #5
Reyes Ribera - ASL Narrator
Alyce Slater Reynolds - Policewoman
David Prince - Bailiff

Special Effects Makeup 
Gungaa Tuvshinbat

Photographer 
Ken Arcia 

Concept Created by the DeafHope Team

http://www.deaf-hope.org
http://www.julesdameron.com

TRANSCRIPT:

Black background with white words: Taking Responsibility.

A woman and a young girl hurries across a room in a house. An angry-looking man follows them. 

A woman is jogging then stops in front of a house with the door open. The woman and young girl are attempting to leave, but the man grabs her and pushes her back inside. A suitcase falls down the front steps. The door slams shut. The jogger shakes her head and starts running again.

A woman drives along in a black jeep. She stops in front of the same house and peeks out through her car window. She witnesses the woman and young girl attempting to leave. The man grabs her and pushes her back inside. The driver drives on.

A close up scene of the woman and young girl attempting to leave. The man grabs her by the throat and pushes her back in. He closes the door with his other arm. A woman (a friend) walks up the door, looks unsure, then walks away. 

A black screen appears with the text "A few ____ later." Pink words appear, making it "A few hours later." 

The driver drives past the house again and sees the door open with the woman on the floor, covered in bruises with an EMT tending to her. A close up shot of the woman's face shows her being badly beaten. The EMT is feeling her pulse. The driver looks distraught. 

A black screen appears with the text "A few ____ later." Pink words appear, making it "A few weeks later." 

The jogger runs along a graveyard. She stops and starts walking toward a tombstone, looking shocked. She looks very upset, with her hands on her legs. A framed picture of the woman is in front of it. The jogger looks extremely upset.

A black screen appears with the text "A few ____ later." Pink words appear, making it "A few months later." 

The scene appears to be a party. A man and a woman are chatting and laughing. Suddenly, the man (abuser) appears, grabs the woman's arm, and leads her away. The (new) woman looks sad and defeated. The friend looks on.

A man in plaid shirt appears in black and white. He signs "You're responsible too." with white text appearing. 

Everything appears in reverse (the party scene, the graveyard scene, the EMT scene.) 

A black screen appears with the text "Community Accountability."

The same scene is shown with the woman and young girl attempting to leave. The jogger intervenes this time and helps them leave. The jogger leaves while the abuser looks on. 

A black screen appears with the text "Call 911/e911."

The woman in the black jeep makes a phone call. The abuser is shown being led out of the house by a police officer. 

A black screen appears with the text "Give support."

The woman and the friend are sitting together. It appears to be an office or a courtroom. An U.S. flag is next to them. The abuser is in handcuffs, being led by a officer. The woman (survivor) looks nervous with the friend holding her arm. 

A black screen appears with the text "Community Accountability." The text fades. New text appears: "begins with" "you."

DeafHope's logo appears. It is a drawing of a woman holding an infant with one hand and signing ILY with another. Text appears: "Our mission at DeafHope is to end domestic and sexual violence against Deaf women and children through empowerment, education, and services." 

"Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women." 

"www.deaf-hope.org"

Logos for Blue Shield of California and Verizon Foundation appear.

Concept Created by the DeafHope Team

http://www.deaf-hope.org
http://www.julesdameron.com

TRANSCRIPT:

Black background with white words: Taking Responsibility.

A woman and a young girl hurries across a room in a house. An angry-looking man follows them. 

A woman is jogging then stops in front of a house with the door open. The woman and young girl are attempting to leave, but the man grabs her and pushes her back inside. A suitcase falls down the front steps. The door slams shut. The jogger shakes her head and starts running again.

A woman drives along in a black jeep. She stops in front of the same house and peeks out through her car window. She witnesses the woman and young girl attempting to leave. The man grabs her and pushes her back inside. The driver drives on.

A close up scene of the woman and young girl attempting to leave. The man grabs her by the throat and pushes her back in. He closes the door with his other arm. A woman (a friend) walks up the door, looks unsure, then walks away. 

A black screen appears with the text "A few ____ later." Pink words appear, making it "A few hours later." 

The driver drives past the house again and sees the door open with the woman on the floor, covered in bruises with an EMT tending to her. A close up shot of the woman's face shows her being badly beaten. The EMT is feeling her pulse. The driver looks distraught. 

A black screen appears with the text "A few ____ later." Pink words appear, making it "A few weeks later." 

The jogger runs along a graveyard. She stops and starts walking toward a tombstone, looking shocked. She looks very upset, with her hands on her legs. A framed picture of the woman is in front of it. The jogger looks extremely upset.

A black screen appears with the text "A few ____ later." Pink words appear, making it "A few months later." 

The scene appears to be a party. A man and a woman are chatting and laughing. Suddenly, the man (abuser) appears, grabs the woman's arm, and leads her away. The (new) woman looks sad and defeated. The friend looks on.

A man in plaid shirt appears in black and white. He signs "You're responsible too." with white text appearing. 

Everything appears in reverse (the party scene, the graveyard scene, the EMT scene.) 

A black screen appears with the text "Community Accountability."

The same scene is shown with the woman and young girl attempting to leave. The jogger intervenes this time and helps them leave. The jogger leaves while the abuser looks on. 

A black screen appears with the text "Call 911/e911."

The woman in the black jeep makes a phone call. The abuser is shown being led out of the house by a police officer. 

A black screen appears with the text "Give support."

The woman and the friend are sitting together. It appears to be an office or a courtroom. An U.S. flag is next to them. The abuser is in handcuffs, being led by a officer. The woman (survivor) looks nervous with the friend holding her arm. 

A black screen appears with the text "Community Accountability." The text fades. New text appears: "begins with" "you."

DeafHope's logo appears. It is a drawing of a woman holding an infant with one hand and signing ILY with another. Text appears: "Our mission at DeafHope is to end domestic and sexual violence against Deaf women and children through empowerment, education, and services." 

"Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women." 

"www.deaf-hope.org"

Logos for Blue Shield of California and Verizon Foundation appear.

Our sons can become amazing athletes without degrading girls and women.  

Join the effort to END the gender war by volunteering at a Domestic Violence agency.

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/B7of/

LAVENDER REVOLUTION - a social media movement to end violence against women.

During past 5 years, more than 6,000 American women have been killed by their spouses and lovers in our own country.

This is more than the 4,000 U.S. soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan combined during the same time period.

Domestic Violence is a WAR ZONE!

We cannot ignore this WAR against our daughters anymore.

Join the effort to END the gender war by volunteering at a Domestic Violence agency.

More info at http://www.deaf-hope.org

Thanks to San Diego public library - Mission Hills library

Co-written & produced by Julie Rems-Smario
Co-written & acted by Deanne Bray
Director of Photographer & edited by Jon Savage
Audio edited by Len Savage

***If you or someone you know is in a DV situation and needs help, contact your local DV agency. 

If you are in California or there is nothing available nearby, contact Deaf Hope at hotline@deaf-hope.org from Monday-Friday 9am-5pm.

For general information on Deaf Hope, see our website at www.deaf-hope.org***

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/B7of/

title.$t: "Never Underestimate the POWER of Deaf Women" Series [3 of 3]

media$title.$t: "Never Underestimate the POWER of Deaf Women" Series [3 of 3]

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/B7oe/

DeafHope is excited to introduce a series,"Never Underestimate the POWER of Deaf Women" to showcase inspiring Deaf women sharing their wisdom with Deaf women everywhere. 

DeafHope's Julie Rems-Smario and Natty Franck had the opportunity to travel to Burbank, California to meet 10 wonderful Deaf women who shared their experience of breaking down barriers they faced in the past. The third vlog of three presents four Deaf women from the Greater Los Angeles Area: 

Kavita Pipalia, Leader & Activist for the Deaf & Hard of Hearing Community
Kalen Feeney, Actress & Screenwriter
Lisa Hermatz, ASL Singer/Performer


Directed & Shot by Jules Dameron
Gaffer Arleta Meeker
Edited by Erik Call & Jules Dameron
Thanks to Sean Berdy & Sharon Dror

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/B7oe/

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/B7ob/

LAVENDER REVOLUTION - a social media movement to end violence against women

Very great change starts from very small conversations, held among people who care. - Margaret Wheatley

We must remember that one determined person can make a significant difference, and that a small group of determined people can change the course of history. - Sonia Johnson 

The future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams. - Eleanor Roosevelt

Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women!
More info at http://deaf-hope.org

Director of Photographed & Edited by Jon Savage

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/B7o8/

LAVENDER REVOLUTION - a social media movement to end violence against women

Men are living in the mistaken belief that they cannot be raped because "rape is a women's issue"

Women are constantly striving to protect their bodies using many different ways, yet they are still being raped EVERYDAY!

A man is raped everyday usually by other men. A woman is raped EVERY TWO MINUTES, usually by someone they know. Men are impacted by the constant Violence against women...

Deaf men and women can accomplish so much MORE by working together to END RAPE CULTURE!

Every time we liberate a woman, we liberate a man. ~Margaret Mead

Join DeafHope's effort to end violence against women!

More info at http://deaf-hope.org

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/B7o8/

media$description.$t:
Help us caption and translate this video on Amara.org: http://www.amara.org/en/v/B7pT/

The Bay Area community organized this presentation, Are You a Sexist, to start awareness about how homophobia and heterosexism is a form of sexism. Sexism is the root of the rape culture currently ingrained in our society. One to five transgendered people are murdered. LGBT people live everyday with the threat of being bullied, beaten, raped, and even murdered. Through awareness, LGBT people and Allies together have the power to create a safe place free of oppression and violence for everyone.
Filmed & Edited by Martha Anger
Credits by:
Ken Arcia
Brian Berlinski-Berry
Amber Hodson
Daniel Langholtz
Drago Renteria
Vanessa Sandez
Julie Rems-Smario
Marilyn Smith
Lisa Marie Wilson
Nora Yates
The Cast:
Ree Ree Brown
Martin Dale-Hench
Natalee Franck
Shira Grabelsky
Alise Marie Harding
Leala Holcomb
Tara Holcomb
Antoine Hunter
Katie Murch
Jane Whitney
Lynnette Williams

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/B7pT/
